occurrences.line_text: Does tremble: for his deepe deuouring iawes
That yet I quake and tremble ouer all.
And inly tremble at the memory
That seem'd to tremble euermore, and quake:
To moue, and tremble as it were agast,
Did liuely seeme to tremble, wheh she saw
That euerie word did tremble as she spake,
Her hart did leape, and all her hart-strings tremble,
Began to quake and tremble with dismay;
Make th'heauens tremble oft, & him with vowes asswage.
Began to tremble euery limbe and vaine;
That euery foote did tremble, which did tread,
And made the wood to tremble at the noyce:
The knight himselfe euen trembled at his fall,
His hand, that trembled, as one terrifyde;
And trembled, as them passing they beheld:
But trembled like a lambe, fled from the pray,
But trembled vnderneath his mighty hand,
And their greene leaues trembling with euery blast,
At last she vp gan lift: with trembling cheare
And seizing cruell clawes on trembling brest,
Trembling through hasty rage, whe[n] choler in him sweld.
And many Bardes, that to the trembling chord
The trembling ghosts with sad amazed mood,
And trembling yet through feare of former hate;
Such fearefull fit assaid her trembling hart,
His trembling hand he would him force to put
Which through the tre[m]bling leaues full gently playes
With foltring tong, and trembling euery vaine,
But trembling feare did feele in euery vaine;
And trembling with strange feare, did like an earthquake show.
And trembling horrour ran through euery ioynt,
But trembling euery ioynt did inly quake,
Whiles trembling horror did his conscience dant,
He smote his courser in the trembling flancke,
Each trembling leafe, and whistling wind they heare,
Vpon the trembling waue, so shined bright,
And trembling Feare still to and fro did fly,
With trembling hand his troubled pulse gan try;
Long trembling still he stood: at last thus sayd;
Still waites for death with dread and trembling aw;
And trembling terror did his hart apall,
So riu'd her trembling hart, and wicked end did make.
Vpon the waues to spred her trembling light,
The trembling groues, the Christall running by;
Th'Angelicall soft trembling voyces made
Whose hideous horror and sad trembling sound
Then panting soft, and trembling euerie ioynt,
And euery trembling ioynt, and euery vaine
Trembling with horrour, as that did foresee
And rubd his temples, and each trembling vaine;
A trembling Culuer, hauing spide on hight
Then trembling yet through feare, the Squire bespake,
But trembling stood, and yielded him the pray;
Then tooke he him yet trembling sith of late,
Trembling through feare, least down he fallen should,
They trembling stood, and made a long broad dyke,
At that wide orifice her trembling hart
Trembling in heart, and looking pale and wan,
Whilest trembling horrour did his sense assayle,
Yet trembling euery ioynt through former feare;
Came to that Squire, yet trembling euery vaine:
The trembling foule dismayd with dreadfull sight
With trembling ioynts, as he for terrour shooke;
In his right hand he held a trembling dart,
And with his trenchand blade her boldly kept
And fiercely tooke his trenchand blade in hand,
For with his trenchant blade at the next blow
And bounteous Trent, that in him selfe enseames
Bidding his beades all day for his trespas,
The trespasse still doth liue, albe the person die.
As if no trespasse euer had bene donne:
Amends may for the trespasse soone be made,
Some one, whose tongue was for his trespasse vyle
How euer they through treason doe trespasse.
That almost had against you trespassed this day.
And wrapt in fetters of a golden tresse,
The faire Medina with her tresses torne,
Was trimly wouen, and in tresses wrought,
Her golden lockes, that late in tresses bright
Into their comely tresses dewly drest,
Sir Treuisan flies from Despayre,
I that hight Treuisan (quoth he) will ride
The wofull tale that Treuisan had told,
He taught to imitate that Lady trew,
Her vp he tooke, too simple and too trew,
Trew sacred lore, which from her sweet lips did redound.
On gentle Dame, so hurtlesse, and so trew:
Or heard abroad of that her champion trew,
But thou his errour shalt, I hope now prouen trew.
With bloud of guiltlesse babes, and innocents trew,
O welcome thou, that doest of death bring tydings trew.
And loue establish each to other trew,
Which piteous spectacle, approuing trew
And trew Repentance they to Vna brought:
Most trew, then said the holy aged man;
Or false or trew, or liuing or else dead,
The Amazon huge riuer now found trew?
Of knighthood trew, and is of fayre
The scorne of knighthood and trew cheualrye,
With which Acontius got his louer trew,
And my trew liegeman yield thy selfe for ay,
Which when he heard, and saw the tokens trew,
What mote ye weene, if the trew liuely-head
Well weeting trew, what she had rashly told;
That hight Phantastes by his nature trew;
Would surely deeme it to be yuie trew:
Who can it doe more liuely, or more trew,
That truth is strong, and trew loue most of might,
The saluage minds with skill of iust and trew;
Of hunter swift, and sent of houndes trew.
And honour of trew Ladies, if ye may
Hauing him trew and faithfull euer tride,
Her nourced had in trew Nobility:
Hard is to teach an old horse amble trew.
To be his Leman and his Ladie trew:
Then said, Faire Sir, how may I weene it trew,
That was as trew in loue, as Turtle to her make.
And fiercely ronning to that Lady trew,
So could she forge all colours, saue the trew.
Till Blandamour, who thought he had the trew
To hide his falshood, then if it were trew:
Delightfull bowres, to solace louers trew;
Trew Ionathan, and Dauid trustie tryde;
Mother of blessed Peace, and Friendship trew;
Could weenen, whether they were false or trew.
And why? doe it declare vnto me trew.
The right or wrong, the false or else the trew?
As if before she had not counted trew.
The knights beleeu'd, that all he sayd, was trew,
To wend with him, and be his conduct trew
The iustest man and trewest in his dayes,
Sir knight with-hold, till further triall made.
Iwote (quoth he) whom triall late did teach,
By triall of his former harmes and cares,
To make more triall of his hardiment,
And by long triall of the inward griefe,
That well can witnesse, who by triall it does proue.
Who through late triall, on that wealthy Strond
Till triall doe more certaine truth bewray.
Yet was it in due triall but a wandring weft.
That I too true by triall haue approued:
Excludes from fairest hope, withouten further triall.
And triall, whether should the honor get.
Which well I proue, as shall appeare by triall,
That battels vtmost triall to aduenter.
And then and there for triall of her right
But in the triall of true curtesie,
In which they mote make triall of their might,
Couragious Cambell, and stout Triamond,
The second Dyamond, the youngest Triamond.
But Triamond was stout and strong alike:
On horsebacke vsed Triamond to fight,
And Triamond to handle speare and shield,
Streight entring into Triamond, him fild
Yet nought thereof was Triamond adredde,
Sir Triamond at last full faint and feeble stood.
Which Triamond perceiuing, weened sure
For Triamond had Canacee to wife,
Twixt Cambell and Sir Triamond befell,
But Triamond halfe wroth to see him staid,
Which doughty Triamond had wrought that day,
There where he saw the valiant Triamond
But mongst them all, was not Sir Triamond,
Which Triamond had worne, vnwares to wight,
Whereof when newes to Triamond was brought,
To Triamond and Cambell as the best.
But Triamond to Cambell it relest,
And Cambell it to Triamond transferd;
Whereat full inly wroth was Triamond,
The second was to Triamond behight,
Next did Sir Triamond vnto their sight
Then was she iudged Triamond his one;
But Triamond lou'd Canacee, and other none.
And part triangulare, Ã´ worke diuine;
Such as the Angels weare before Gods tribunall.
Of Magistrates, of courts, of tribunals,
Thenceforth this land was tributarie made
And of them both did foy and tribute raise,
For that their tribute he refusd to let be payd.
And tribute eke withall, as to his Soueraine.
To him, as to their Lord, and tribute pay:
And tribute backe repay as to their King.
And many pleasant trickes before her show,
Small drops of gory bloud, that trickled downe the same.
From vnder which fast trickled downe the sweat:
From which fast trickled forth a siluer flood,
And fast beside, there trickled softly downe
Deawed with siluer drops, that trickled downe alway.
A trickling streame from high rocke tumbling downe
The red bloud trickling staind the way, as he did ride.
In which yet trickling bloud and gobbets raw
A trickling streame of Balme, most soueraine
Few trickling teares she softly forth let fall,
Did tricle downe her haire, like to the hore
Till I that treachours art haue heard and tride;
To melt the golden metall, ready to be tride.
There she with them a cruell battell tride,
Aboue all knights, that euer battell tride,
Hauing him trew and faithfull euer tride,
For all this worlds faire workmanship she tride,
And had in many a battell oft bene tride,
Then many other Ladies likewise tride,
That pittie is to heare the perils, which she tride.
After late weary toile, which she had tride
(Whereof it hight) and hauing shortly tride
But sooth is said, and tride in each degree,
All twenty tride in warres experience long;
Yet many doughty warriours, often tride
Can hardly but by Sacrament be tride,
And both in armes well traind and throughly tride.
Well then, sayd Artegall, let it be tride.
And put two wrongs together to be tride,
A noble Knight, and tride in hard assayes:
Or if it were not Florimell so tride,
And Queene of Amazons, in armes well tride,
But he that had like tempests often tride,
Till thou haue tride againe, & tempted him more neare.
Well tride in all thy Ladies troubles than,
Then he was tride vnto his Lady bright:
And rather had to lose, then trie in armes his right.
By law of armes there neede ones right to trie,
I will not rest, till I her might doe trie,
He thether came, but for to trie the right
Thinking the vtmost of their force to trie,
To lend him day his better right to trie,
Yet tried did adore. Supper was dight;
And then it shall be tried, if ye will,
To rip vp wrong, that battell once hath tried;
The falsest man aliue; who tries shall find no lesse.
That like pure Orient perles adowne it trild,
A litle Gondelay, bedecked trim
And fragrant violets, and Pances trim,
That wonder was to heare their trim consort.
The whiles the maskers marched forth in trim aray.
And comely carriage of her count'nance trim,
Some prancke their ruffes, and others trimly dight
Was trimly wouen, and in tresses wrought,
For Coridon could daunce, and trimly trace.
In their trinall triplicities on hye;
And triple crowne set on her head full hye,
A triple warre with triple enmitee,
A triple warre with triple enmitee,
In their trinall triplicities on hye;
Calidore sees young Tristram slay
And Tristram is my name, the onely heire
Full glad and ioyous then young Tristram grew,
Chyld Tristram prayd, that he with him might goe
But Tristram then despoyling that dead knight
This knight, whom Tristram slew, had wounded sore
(Whom Tristram slew) them in that shadow found,
That this was he, whom Tristram earst did slay,
Of noble Tristram, where it did remaine:
They were all taught by Triton, to obay
Triton his trompet shrill before them blew,
At last the trumpets Triumph sound on hie,
But thy dread darts in none doe triumph more,
And gan thereat to triumph without victorie.
And of your gotten spoyle their owne triumph to make.
For goodly triumph and great iollyment,
Thereat she gan to triumph with great boast,
Like a triumphall Arch, and thereupon
Come both, and with you bring triumphant Mart,
Then gan triumphant Trompets sound on hie,
Did shew her selfe in great triumphant ioy,
She gan reioyce, and shew triumphant chere,
Triumphed oft against her enimis;
She triumphed on death, in enemies despight.
Thus I triumphed long in louers paine,
By which she triumphes ouer ire and pride,
For Loue his loftie triumphes to engraue,
And triumphes of PhlegrÃ¦an Ioue he wrote,
Of many wretches set his triumphes hye,
And now triumphest in the piteous spoile
Triumphing in great ioy and iolity;
He chaunst to come, far from all peoples troad,
Where foot of liuing creature neuer troade,
Would haue cast downe, and trod in durtie myre,
And is behinde me trodden downe of Scorne,
The fierce Spumador trode them downe like docks,
But wholy wast, and void of peoples trode,
And trode downe in the durt, where his hore beard
And nicely trode, as thornes lay in his way,
The other backe retired, and contrarie trode.
They trode, and on the ground their liues did strow,
Vpon the ground with feeble feete he trode,
Till that at length she found the troden gras,
Troden in dust with fury insolent,
Despisd and troden downe of all that ouerran.
That euer troden was of footings trace.
Shall spring, out of the auncient Troian blood,
The royall seed, the antique Troian blood,
Of Greekish bloud so oft in Troian plaine;
Which they far off beheld from Troian toures,
Gathred the Troian reliques sau'd from flame,
Of Troian warres, and Priams Citie sackt,
The Troian Brute did first that Citie found,
That of the antique Troian stocke, there grew
The Troiane flames, and reach to heauens hight
Againe, when as the Troiane boy so faire
That many noble Greekes and Troians made to bleed.
For noble Britons sprong from Troians bold,
With all the warlike youth of Troians bloud,
Out of the Troians scattered of-spring,
Of Greekes and Troians, which therein did die;
Trompart fit man for Braggadocchio,
And comming close to Trompart gan inquere
But Trompart stoutly stayd to taken heed,
Such when as hartlesse Trompart her did vew,
Trompart forth stept, to stay the mortall chaunce,
But turning said to Trompart, What foule blot
Perdie (said Trompart) let her passe at will,
And hauing her from Trompart lightly reard,
That with his seruant Trompart houerd there,
Till Trompart ronning hastily, him did stay,
What Ladie, man? (said Trompart) take good hart,
But Trompart, that his maisters humor knew,
Till Trompart lowly to the ground inclind,
Ah but (said craftie Trompart) weete ye well,
Said Trompart, You that are the most opprest
And after him eke fearefull Trompart sped;
Where when he found it not (for Trompart bace
Whom Trompart had in keeping there beside,
On Tromparts steed her mounted without stay,
Soone as thy dreadfull trompe begins to sownd;
In her eternall trompe, with laurell girland cround.
That fame in trompe of gold eternally displayes.
Where I with sound of trompe will also rest a whyle.
A shrilling trompet sownded from on hye,
Which fame of her shrill trompet worthy reedes:
She heard a shrilling Trompet sound aloud,
A trompet blew; they both together met,
Triton his trompet shrill before them blew,
Then gan triumphant Trompets sound on hie,
With shaumes, & trompets, & with Clarions sweet;
Their murmuring small trompets sounden wide,
And when it ceast, shrill trompets loud did bray,
The whiles shril trompets & loud clarions sweetly playd.
His foe was soone addrest: the trompets freshly blew.
Then shrilling trompets loudly gan to bray,
No warre was knowne, no dreadfull trompets sound,
The trompets sound; then all together ronne.
But at the last the trompets did proclame
Then did the trompets sound, and Iudges rose,
Of all that Tryumph. Then the trompets shrill
The trompets sound, and they together goe,
But th'other did vpon his troncheon smyte,
Yet with his troncheon he so rudely stroke
And in his hand nought but the troncheon left,
And in their hands their idle troncheons held,
The headlesse tronke, as heedlesse of that stower,
Were much amaz'd the headlesse tronke to see
That headlesse tyrants tronke he reard from ground,
But forst to trot on foot, and foule misused,
None but that saw (quoth he) would weene for troth,
But could not colour yet so well the troth,
Soone shalt thou see, and then beleeue for troth,
And all the way from trotting hard to spare,
For seldome seene, a trotting Stalion get
Tydings of warre and worldly trouble tell?
He seekes out mighty charmes, to trouble sleepy mindes
Who oft is wont to trouble gentle Sleepe.
Indeede (quoth she) that should her trouble sore,
And trouble dying soules tranquilitee.
From needlesse trouble of renewing fight
To trouble my still seate, and heapes of pretious pelfe.
Whereof great trouble in the kingdome grew,
Sore trouble of an hainous enimy;
At last with irkesome trouble she abrayd;
To be most fit to trouble noble knights,
Tumultuous trouble and contentious iarre,
Fild with false rumors and seditious trouble,
By heaping stormes of trouble on them daily more?
Which him had sought through trouble & lo[n]g strife;
To peace, then needlesse trouble to constraine.
For him to trouble she it thought vnfit,
Is tost with troubled sights and fancies weake,
That with their sturre they troubled all the traine;
Which troubled once, into huge flames will grow,
And troubled bloud through his pale face was seene
Through the dull billowes thicke as troubled mire,
Troubled with terrour and vnquiet iarre,
With trembling hand his troubled pulse gan try;
Faire Damzell, seemeth, by your troubled cheare,
And to the troubled chamber all in armes did throng.
Full many wayes within her troubled mind,
Ouer the troubled South, that it shall make
Which in these troubled bowels raignes, & rageth rife.
To calme the tempest of his troubled thought:
Such as the troubled Theaters oftimes annoyes.
It doth establish in the troubled mynd.
Hath troubled both your mindes with idle thought,
Did comfort take, or in his troubled sight
Was troubled sore, ne wist well what to weene,
And inly troubled was, the truth to learne.
But rather gan in troubled mind deuize,
He much was troubled, ne wist what to doo.
But most she did her troubled mynd molest,
Yet found no easement in her troubled wits,
As being troubled with that stormy stowre;
Beheld, it much appald her troubled spright:
But gathered vnto her her troubled wit,
The which they troubled had with great turmoyle.
Of their arriuall: wherewith troubled sore,
And troubled had their quiet loues delight.
From his deuotion streight he troubled was;
Like troubled ghost did dreadfully appeare,
He much was troubled at that straungers guize,
Much was the Lady troubled at that speach,
(Quoth he) the troubler of my happie peace,
But were it not, that Time their troubler is,
And in her many troubles did most pleasure take.
Of her sad troubles and misfortunes hard:
By traynes into new troubles to haue tost:
Blaming of Fortune, which such troubles threw,
For whose deare sake so many troubles her did tosse.
After long troubles and vnmeet vpbrayes,
Well tride in all thy Ladies troubles than,
In seas of troubles and of toylesome paine,
That her to see should be but troublesome.
Such was betwixt these two the troublesome vprore.
Thinking to hide the depth by troubling of the flood.
With many idle stoups her troubling still:
Groning full deadly, all with troublous feare,
No other noyse, nor peoples troublous cryes,
That troublous dreame gan freshly tosse his braine,
Vnto his guest, who after troublous sights
Whom broad awake she finds, in troublous fit,
And fill the fields with troublous bellowing,
As a tall ship tossed in troublous seas,
To which his flowing toung, and troublous spright
Some troublous vprore or contentious fray,
Does ouerthrow, and troublous warre proclame:
By fortune came, led with the troublous sowne:
Long were to tell the troublous stormes, that tosse
That breathed strife and troublous enmitie;
Thus when they had that troublous rout disperst,
This is the Port of rest from troublous toyle,
That with so troublous terrour they were all dismayde.
To stirre vp strife, and troublous contecke broch:
In stead of sleepe thou sendest troublous feares,
Thus whilest all things in troublous vprore were,
All suddenly they heard a troublous noyes,
Which troublous stirre when Satyrane auiz'd:
High Swale, vnquiet Nide, and troublous Skell;
Which troublous stirre when Artegall perceiued,
But tossed in her troublous minde, what way
The troublous passion of my pensiue mind,
That Knight shall all the troublous stormes asswage,
She much was eased in her troublous thought,
She was confused in her troublous thought,
All full of people making troublous din,
In troublous wits, and mutinous vprore:
That haue her drawne to all this troublous strife,
To stint all strife and troublous enmitie,
A troupe of Faunes and Satyres far away
And all the troupe of light-foot Naiades,
The first troupe was a monstrous rablement
Gainst which the second troupe dessignment makes;
Of that third troupe was cruelly assayd:
But the fift troupe most horrible of hew,
One day, when all that troupe of warlike wooers
There he in troupe found all that warlike crew,
At length they came, whereas a troupe of Knights
To be a troupe of women warlike dight,
Dispersed all their troupe incontinent,
And now he hath this troupe of villains sent,
So forth they rode together all in troupe,
There he a troupe of Ladies dauncing found
Great troupes of people traueild thitherward
Wherewith the martiall troupes thou doest infest,
Broke their rude troupes, and orders did confound,
Them in twelue troupes their Captain did dispart
Thus these twelue troupes with dreadfull puissance
The rest them selues in troupes did else dispose,
That did amongst the troupes so tyrannize;
And with their troupes did far a sunder cast:
Did set vpon those troupes with all his powre and might.
Maugre the might of all those troupes in vew,
Whose presence all their troups so much encombred
Their thickest troups, & round about him scattreth wide.
And were I not, yet is my trouth yplight,
And henceforth by this dayes ensample trow,
Is, that she is the fairest wight aliue, I trow.
Or faile thereof, so much is more then iust to trow.
Sad Trowis/, that once his people ouerran,
To succour the weake state of sad afflicted Troy.
Nor that proud towre of Troy, though richly guilt,
Troy, that art now nought, but an idle name,
That warre was kindled, which did Troy inflame,
Who long before the ten yeares siege of Troy,
And Troy againe out of her dust was reard,
Both first and second Troy shall dare to equalise.
Matchable either to that ympe of Troy,
And Troynouant was built of old Troyes ashes cold.
Of Troynouant, gainst force of enimy,
And Troynouant was built of old Troyes ashes cold.
It Troynouant is hight, that with the waues
His worke great Troynouant, his worke is eke
That was to weet the famous Troynouant,
